This is the date of the article's publication, when updated polling data on public opinion regarding Trump's Gaza deal and economic policies is being reported.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period between the Gaza ceasefire deal announcement and the article's publication highlights the rapid deterioration of public confidence in the deal and in Trump’s leadership, especially amid economic concerns.

keyTakeAways: Americans show little enthusiasm for Trump’s handling of the Gaza ceasefire deal, despite its international acclaim.
Trump’s approval ratings remain low, with 37% approval and 61% disapproval in an AP-NORC poll, marking one of his worst ratings since 2017.

A CNBC poll shows Americans disapproving of Trump’s handling of the economy at 52% to 44%, and of inflation and cost of living at 62% to 34% — his worst net approval on economic issues in either term.
Public pessimism is rising: only 32% of Americans expect economic improvement in the next year, and only 31% expect wage increases.
Employed Americans are increasingly worried about job loss — only 52% say they are not at all worried, a drop from previous years.
Foreign policy issues, including Gaza, are low on Americans’ priority list: just 4% ranked international events as the top issue in a CBS News-YouGov poll.
Three-fourths of Americans believe Trump has not done enough to lower prices, indicating a strong public focus on economic realities over diplomatic outcomes.
Despite some initial positive reactions to the Gaza deal, public sentiment appears to be lukewarm or skeptical due to economic concerns and historical patterns of peace deal failures.
The article suggests that Americans prioritize economic issues over foreign policy achievements, especially when those achievements appear unstable or short-lived.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Despite the announcement of a Gaza ceasefire deal, which was initially celebrated as a diplomatic triumph, American public opinion remains largely unimpressed and skeptical. Trump’s approval ratings on both the Gaza deal and broader economic policy have declined, with the economy — especially inflation and cost of living — becoming the dominant concern. Polling data from AP-NORC and CNBC reveal that Americans disapprove of Trump’s leadership on economic issues at record levels, and that public pessimism about the economy and job security is rising. The article argues that foreign policy achievements, even major ones, are overshadowed by domestic economic anxieties, with many Americans prioritizing economic stability over international diplomacy. This reflects a broader trend where public trust in Trump is rooted more in economic performance than in foreign policy outcomes.
title: Americans shrug at Trump’s Gaza deal, as economic fears reign
